data.title: TV - Uninstall BBC iplayer from smart TV (Panasonic)

data.text:
I am going to cancel my TV Licence and i am making sure that i am obeying the law before cancelling and that i have no means of watching live tv or record TV and watching the BBC Iplayer

So far i have de-tuned the TV's in the house and removed the aerials, even sold my Samsung Blu ray smart player with built in recorder and tv tuner, The only thing left to do is to remove the BBC Iplayer apps which i am finding it impossible to do because it doesn't give me a option. only this i can do is to sign out of the apps, i will try and delete my BBC Account.

With the TV licencing employing Capita to go knocking on houses who don't have a licence and scaring people with letters, I want to be 100% sure that they cannot get me on anything.

Some apps on smart TVs can't be deleted by the user. This level of control, or lack thereof, will have been decided by the manufacturer and perhaps the app owner has a say in it as well, such as it being a condition of the manufacture being allowed access to that app.

As I understand it - the law requiring a licence requires you to actually use the equipment for a licenced purpose. Whether you own such a device or not isn't relevant. The onus would be on them to prove such use. Although inability of the equipment to be used in this manner is an easy defence, I don't think it's a necessity.

The requirement for a license is not exclusively attached to BBC transmissions. It is NOT, as many people think, a BBC TV Licence. The exact wording from the authority reads:

You don’t need a TV Licence if you never watch or record programmes as they’re being shown on TV, on any channel, or live on an online TV service, and you never download or watch BBC programmes on iPlayer – live, catch up or on demand.

This applies to any provider or device you use, including a TV, desktop computer, laptop, mobile phone, tablet, games console, digital box or Blu-ray/DVD/VHS recorder.

Note the words "on any channel"

Don’t you need an account to use iPlayer now - delete that account - put the request into the BBC if need be.

Actually, sure I have had to sign in at some point but just checked the web version and you just get a prompt saying “do you have a licence”. You just say ”I wouldn’t use the app any way because I am not entitled to but if I accidentally opened it when I get that I say ‘NO‘ I don’t have a licence and it won’t let me continue”.

If that is the only level of protect that the BBC implement you can’t do any more.

Cheers,

Nigel

You don’t need a TV Licence if you never watch or record programmes as they’re being shown on TV, on any channel, or live on an online TV service, and you never download or watch BBC programmes on iPlayer – live, catch up or on demand.

This applies to any provider or device you use, including a TV, desktop computer, laptop, mobile phone, tablet, games console, digital box or Blu-ray/DVD/VHS recorder.

Note the words "on any channel"

Just so I'm clear, without a TV Licence, you must avoid any live broadcast on any service?

That is correct, You cannot watch nothing live, not even Via Sky.

I have deleted my BBC Account, So i cannot log onto any apps.

I also cancelled my TV Licence this morning, I am not paying for something that i don't use , Youtube is your friend, It has everything that i need

if you have a receiver, (TV), that can receive analogue (now defunct), or digital content, whether freeview, freesat or you never watch BBC you must have a licence, I have freesat plus new LG tv has freeview, also have virgin box, only because when I discussed my bills one year they said if I take the basic TV package it would reduce my bills by £1 a month, so I took it, they called me last week and said I hadn't ued by box for a while, over 6 months, and asked why, so if vm can check so can the licencing authorities, also you should also feel sorry for me, in 4 months I WOULD have had a free tv licence, not going to happen now

if you have a receiver, (TV), that can receive analogue (now defunct), or digital content, whether freeview, freesat or you never watch BBC you must have a licence

Nope.

Just because you have the equipment doesn't mean you have to have a licence.

I have the equipment to watch iPlayer as I have internet and a TV/computer/tablet/phone. It doesn't mean I have to have a licence.

If I don't watch or record any live broadcasts, this means any not just BBC, so no Sky or Virgin either never mind ITV and Ch4, and don't use BBC iPlayer then I don't need a TV licence.

if you have a receiver, (TV), that can receive analogue (now defunct), or digital content, whether freeview, freesat or you never watch BBC you must have a licence,

This is incorrect. It is perfectly OK to have and use equipment capable of receiving/recording live television broadcasts, internet streams of currently television content being simultaneously being broadcast, and the BBC iPlayer without a licence. If you don't have a licence you just have to not actually use the equipment to watch/record live TV broadcasts or use the BBC iPlayer.

Its amazing the amount of people who believe the BBC in saying you need a licence if you have a TV, However , I have made it impossible to watch live TV by de-tuning my TVs, disconnecting the aerials, Deleting BBC Iplayers where possible, So if i get a knock on the door, I know that i am OK, But i will not be answering my door to anyone in the near future due to Corona and i have No cold callers plastered on the front door.
